plants.name: Chrysanthemum morifolium
plants.description: A popular ornamental flowering plant known for its vibrant and diverse flower colors. Chrysanthemums often symbolize autumn and are widely cultivated for fall floral displays.
plants.funFact: Chrysanthemums have been cultivated in China for over 3,000 years and are often associated with longevity and rejuvenation.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub producing large, showy, rose-like flowers. Camellias bloom from mid-autumn through winter, adding bright color when many other plants have stopped flowering.
plants.location: East Asia (Japan, Korea, China) and temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica was one of the first camellias introduced to Europe in the 18th century and remains a beloved ornamental plant.

plants.name: Erica cinerea
plants.description: A low-growing shrub native to Western Europe, producing bell-shaped purple-pink flowers. Often found in heathlands, it blooms in autumn, providing nectar for late-season pollinators.
plants.location: Heathlands of Western Europe (UK, Ireland, France)
plants.funFact: Bell Heather thrives in acidic, nutrient-poor soils and plays a crucial role in heathland ecosystems.

plants.name: Protea cynaroides
plants.description: South Africa's national flower, known for its massive flower heads resembling an artichoke. It blooms in late winter to spring in the Southern Hemisphere, which corresponds to October-November in South Africa.
plants.funFact: The King Protea's flower head is actually a cluster of many small flowers surrounded by colorful bracts.
